chapter: Getting Started with Microbiome Data Analysis in R
heading: Getting Started with Microbiome Data Analysis in R
text: Microbial communities play vital role human health disease. Investigating role microbial communities health disease requires thorough knowledge analytical process. provide step--step analytics guides enable user understand microbial composition present given sample. PART 1 microbiome data analysis workflows intended help users getting started. code part 1 available public GitHub repository. can request consulting service contacting developer using contact form. online version book free licensed Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-NoDerivatives 4.0 International License

heading: 1.1 Install R Environments
text: R free software statistical computing, data analysis, graphics (R Core Team 2021). need install R application personal computer process R programming language. can download install R using steps:Go https://www.r-project.org/.left, Download, click CRAN access mirrors. CRAN (Comprehensive R Archive Network) mirrored nearly 100 registered servers nearly 50 regions world. See CRAN mirror status.https://cloud.r-project.org/ Pick mirror close location, automatically R connect server ready download package files.Select compatible platform download precompiled binary distributions base system, also come contributed packages.

heading: 1.2 Install RStudio Environments
text: RStudio free program integrates R IDE (Integrated Development Environment) implement analytical functionalities (RStudio Team 2021). effective analysis, must install R installing RStudio. intensively use RStudio IDE give us user interface. interested RStudio Desktop, open-source regular desktop application. can install like :Go https://rstudio.com/products/rstudio/.Click RStudio Desktop box move open source edition.Choose preferred license either open source commercial.Select installer compatible operating system.Screen shot RStudio User Interface

heading: 1.3 Install R packages
text:
Install basic packages get analysis started. introduce additional packages within subsequent sections whenever neededDescription selected packages
Location R packages used Book

CRAN (Comprehensive R Archive Network): official repository. Reviewed!

Bioconductor: popular repository bioinformatics software. Reviewed!

Github: popular repository open source projects. Reviewed!
Installing loading packages CRANInstalling loading R packages BioconductorInstalling loading R packages GitHub.
code:
install.packages("packagename")
library("packagename")# Install BiocManager
if (!requireNamespace("BiocManager", quietly = TRUE)) install.packages("BiocManager")
library("BiocManager")

# Then install packages like this:
BiocManager::install("packagename")}
library("packagename")# Install devtools from CRAN
install.packages("devtools")
library(devtools)

# Or the development version from GitHub:
devtools::install_github("r-lib/devtools")
library(devtools)

# Then install any GitHub package like this:

devtools::install_github("githubID/packagename")
library("packagename")

heading: 2.1 What is metadata?
text: Metadata set data describes provides information data. commonly defined data data.Sample metadata described book refers description context individual sample collected specific microbiome study.

heading: 2.2 Metadata structure
text:
Metadata collected different stages (Figure 1) typically organized Excel Google spreadsheet :
metadata table columns represent properties samples.
metadata table rows contain information associated samples.
Typically, first column sample metadata Sample ID, designates key associated individual sample
Sampl ID must unique.
metadata table columns represent properties samples.metadata table rows contain information associated samples.Typically, first column sample metadata Sample ID, designates key associated individual sampleSampl ID must unique.

heading: 2.3 Embedded metadata
text: cases, find metadata detached experimental data.Embedded metadata integrates experimental data especially graphics.Major microbiome analysis platforms require sample metadata, commonly referred mapping file performing downstream analysis.

heading: 2.4 Metadata profiling
text:
Typically, sequencing microbiome DNA, investigators encouraged deposit sequence reads public repository. Sequence Read Archive (SRA) currently best bioinformatics database read information. good thing SRA integrates data NCBI, European Bioinformatics Institute (EBI), DNA Data Bank Japan (DDBJ).
profile metadata associated bushmeat microbiome project number PRJNA477349.demonstrate:
download metadata NCBI-SRA archive.
read metadata file R environment.
create tidy dataframe.
select filter desired metadata
download metadata NCBI-SRA archive.read metadata file R environment.create tidy dataframe.select filter desired metadata

heading: 2.4.1 Downloading metadata using the NCBI-SRA run selector
code:
source("R/common.R")
sraruntable <- read_delim("data/SraRunTable.txt", show_col_types = FALSE)

heading: 2.4.2 How many rows and columns
code: paste("There are", dim(sraruntable)[1], "rows and", dim(sraruntable)[2],"columns in this metadata")[1] "There are 133 rows and 34 columns in this metadata"

text: Getting clear knowledge variables associated sample metadata can help filtering important features.Note fraction columns may needed answer research questions.
code:

heading: 2.5 Tidying and subsetting metadata
text: want sample metadata include desired variables.example desire include sample collection point .e latitude longitude.drop row NA location column.good habit rename, modify replace longer column names meaningful names.select columns create desired metadata downstream analyses.Saving tidy metadata file RDS RData format preserve compressed file.

heading: 2.5.1 Getting s desired metadata
code:
metadata <- sraruntable %>%  
  rename_all(tolower) %>% 
  rename(sample_id = run) %>% 
  drop_na(lat_lon) %>% 
  mutate(
    geo_loc_name = str_replace_all(geo_loc_name, "Tanzania: ", ""),
    geo_loc_name = str_replace_all(geo_loc_name, "The Greater Serengeti Ecosystem", "Serengeti"),
    geo_loc_name = str_replace_all(geo_loc_name, " Ecosystem", ""),
    isolate = str_replace_all(isolate, "_\\d*$", ""),
    lat_lon = str_replace_all(lat_lon, " E$", ""),
    latitude = as.numeric(str_replace_all(lat_lon, " S.*", "")) * -1,
    longitude = as.numeric(str_replace_all(lat_lon, ".*S ", ""))) %>% 
  rename(ecosystem = geo_loc_name) %>%
  rename(description = host) %>% 
  mutate(bases = round(bases/1E6, digits = 0)) %>% 
  select(sample_id, ecosystem, isolate, latitude, longitude, milionbases=bases, description)

saveRDS(metadata, "RDataRDS/metadata.rds")

heading: 2.5.2 Compact structure of the tidy metadata
code:
str(metadata)tibble [133 × 7] (S3: tbl_df/tbl/data.frame)
 $ sample_id  : chr [1:133] "SRR10245277" "SRR10245278" "SRR10245279" "SRR10245280" ...
 $ ecosystem  : chr [1:133] "Serengeti" "Serengeti" "Serengeti" "Selous" ...
 $ isolate    : chr [1:133] "Wildebeest" "Pig" "Eland" "Gazelle" ...
 $ latitude   : num [1:133] -2.15 -2.15 -2.15 -9 -9 ...
 $ longitude  : num [1:133] 34.7 34.7 34.7 37.5 37.5 ...
 $ milionbases: num [1:133] 189 261 155 156 105 188 157 122 128 240 ...
 $ description: chr [1:133] "Connochaetes taurinus" "Suidae" "Tragelaphus oryx" "Gazella" ...

heading: 2.5.3 Any missing values?
text: df_status() funModeling R package excellent quick inspecting variables, missing values, data type total unique variables.Key: q_zeros: quantity missing data; p_zeros: percentage missing data, q_na: quantity NA; p_na: percentage NA, q_inf: quantity infinite values; p_inf: percentage infinity values, type: factor, character, integer numeric; unique: levels variable.
code:
library(funModeling)
metadata <- readRDS("RDataRDS/metadata.rds")
df_status(metadata)     variable q_zeros p_zeros q_na p_na q_inf p_inf      type unique
1   sample_id       0       0    0    0     0     0 character    133
2   ecosystem       0       0    0    0     0     0 character      3
3     isolate       0       0    0    0     0     0 character     18
4    latitude       0       0    0    0     0     0   numeric     22
5   longitude       0       0    0    0     0     0   numeric     23
6 milionbases       0       0    0    0     0     0   numeric     93
7 description       0       0    0    0     0     0 character     20

heading: 2.5.5 Which samples have the smallest number of reads?
text: want use samples smaller number reads computation reasons.Read depth proportional number bases (renamed milionbases)Let’s explore read depth across isolates ecosystem.sort bases ascending order.Looks like top samples smallest number reads ecosystem.
code:
metadata %>% 
  select(isolate, ecosystem, milionbases) %>% 
  arrange(milionbases)# A tibble: 133 × 3
   isolate    ecosystem milionbases

heading: 2.5.6 Distribution across common variable
code:
metadata %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = isolate, y = milionbases, fill = ecosystem)) +
  facet_grid(~ ecosystem) +
  geom_col(position = "dodge") +
  coord_flip() +
  labs(x = "Animal Name", y = "Bases (milion)") +
  theme_light()  + 
  nolegend +
  facetsize12 +
 axislayout

heading: 2.6 Mapping sample collection points
text: Sometimes may good pinpoint sample collection point geographical map better feature comparison. leaflet R package can great job dropping pin corresponding coordinate.Let’s give try.Note samples collected coordinate overlap. can zoom -expand minimize map. Mouse pin see variable label.
code:
library(leaflet)
library(leaflet.esri)
library(leaflet.providers)
library(leaflet.extras)
library(data.table)
library(dplyr)

minLat <- min(metadata$latitude) - 0.1
minLon <- min(metadata$longitude) + 0.1
maxLat <- max(metadata$latitude) + 0.1
maxLon <- max(metadata$longitude) + 0.1

metadata %>%
  leaflet() %>% 
  addProviderTiles(providers$Esri.NatGeoWorldMap) %>%
  fitBounds(minLon, minLat, maxLon, maxLat) %>%
  addMarkers(lng = ~longitude, lat = ~latitude, popup = ~isolate, label = ~ c(isolate)) %>%
  addCircles(color="magenta", radius = log1p(metadata$longitude) * 10)

heading: 2.6.1 Example of screenshots from zoom in-out
text: World map: Geographical location sample collection points.Continent map: Geographical location sample collection points.Country map: Geographical location sample collection points.Site map: Geographical location sample collection points.

heading: 3 Sequencing Data
text: Sequencing data may include:Research projectsFrom Sequence Read Archive (SRA)silico simulation

heading: 3.1 From research projects
text: common sources sequencing data research projects. multiple sequencing platforms . example, Illumina sequencing company uses technologies capable profiling entire microbial communities present environmental. Example include:16S rRNA SequencingShotgun Metagenomic Sequencing

heading: 3.2 From archives such as NCBI-SRA
text: NCBI Sequence Read Archive (SRA) stores sequencing data next generation sequencing platforms. Users can download data SRA archive. minimal steps :

heading: 3.2.1 Install SRA Toolkit on Mac OS.
text: Navigate want install tools, preferably home directory.information click .
code:
curl -LO  https://ftp-trace.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/sra/sdk/3.0.0/sratoolkit.3.0.0-mac64.tar.gz
tar -xf sratoolkit.3.0.0-mac64.tar.gz

export PATH=$HOME/sratoolkit.3.0.0-mac64/bin/:$PATH

heading: 3.2.2 Create a cache root directory
code:
mkdir -p ~/ncbi
echo '/repository/user/main/public/root = "/Volumes/SeagateTMB/SRA/BUSHMEAT/SRR7450"' > ~/ncbi/user-settings.mkfg

heading: 3.2.3 Confirm sra toolkit configuration
text: Command display blue colored dialog.Use tab click c navigate cache tab.Review configuration save s exit x.screenshot SRA configuration.information click .
code: vdb-config -i

heading: 3.2.4 Start downloading the fastq files
text: sure fasterq-dump path.Type fasterq-dump confirm path.Use absolute path like ~/sratoolkit.3.0.0-mac64/bin/fasterq-dump already exported path.example uses absolute path execute fasterq-dump command.Notice output temporary files placed external drive mounted computer.sratoolkit folder home directory.
code:
for (( i = 706; i <= 761; i++ ))
    do
        time ~/sratoolkit.3.0.0-mac64/bin/fasterq-dump SRR7450$i \
        -O /Volumes/SeagateTMB/SRA/BUSHMEAT/SRR7450/ \
        -t /Volumes/SeagateTMB/SRA/BUSHMEAT/SRR7450/tmpfiles \
        --threads 4 \
        --split-3;
    done

heading: 3.3 Simmulated insilico sequencing data
text: insilico data used testing software applying real data.generate insilico data can challenging.demo generating NovaSeq, MiSeq HiSeq insilico sequencing data.

heading: 3.3.1 Demo1: NovaSeq metagenomics data
text: Five novaseq paired fastq files
code:
iss generate \
    --ncbi bacteria viruses archaea -U 15 0 2 \
    --coverage lognormal \
    --n_reads 0.12M \
    --model novaseq \annual report
    --output data/novaseq_01 \
    --compress \
    --seed 1
iss generate \
    --ncbi bacteria viruses archaea -U 15 1 1 \
    --coverage lognormal \
    --n_reads 0.11M \
    --model novaseq \
    --output data/novaseq_02 \
    --compress \
    --seed 2

heading: 3.4 How to resize fastq files
text: Sometimes want extract small subset test bioinformatics pipeline.can resize fastq files using seqkit sample function (Shen2016?; W. Shen 2022).demo extracting 0.1% sequencing data.
code:
mkdir -p data
for i in {706..761}
  do
    cat SRR7450$i\_R1.fastq \
    | seqkit sample -p 0.01 \
    | seqkit shuffle -o data/SRR7450$i\_R1_sub.fastq \
    | cat SRR7450$i\_R2.fastq \
    | seqkit sample -p 0.01 \
    | seqkit shuffle -o data/SRR7450$i\_R2_sub.fastq
  done

heading: 4 Read Processing Tools
text: several tools can help preprocessing raw read. Listed common tools used understanding characteristics read quality scores. Click hyperlinked tool learn install .Seqkit (Wei Shen et al. 2016)FastQC (Andrews 2018)MultiQC (Ewels et al. 2016)BBMap platform (Bushnell 2016)Kneaddata biobakery platform (Biobakery 2022)

heading: 4.1.1 Install seqkit
code:
wget --no-check-certificate https://github.com/shenwei356/seqkit/releases/download/v0.8.0/seqkit_darwin_amd64.tar.gz
tar -zxvf seqkit_darwin_amd64.tar.gz
mv seqkit code/
cp code/seqkit ~/bin/
rm seqkit_darwin_amd64.tar.gz

heading: 4.1.2 Install fastqc
code:
wget --no-check-certificate https://www.bioinformatics.babraham.ac.uk/projects/fastqc/fastqc_v0.11.7.zip
unzip fastqc_v0.11.7.zip
chmod 755 FastQC/fastqc
mv -v FastQC code/
cp code/FastQC/fastqc ~/bin/
rm fastqc_v0.11.7.zip

heading: 4.1.3 Install bbmap
text: Make sure check latest instructions online.
code:
wget --no-check-certificate https://sourceforge.net/projects/bbmap/files/BBMap_37.90.tar.gz
tar -xvzf BBMap_37.90.tar.gz
mv -v bbmap code/
cp code/bbmap/bbduk.sh ~/bin/
rm BBMap_37.90.tar.gz

heading: A.4 How to reload RDS or RData into R environment
text:
RDS format e.g. foo.rds

foo <- readRDS(“RDataRDS/foo.rds”)


foo <- readRDS(“RDataRDS/foo.rds”)

RData format e.g. foo.RData

load(“RDataRDS/foo.RData,” verbose = TRUE)


load(“RDataRDS/foo.RData,” verbose = TRUE)

List objects RData

lsdata(“foo.RData”)


lsdata(“foo.RData”)
